skills.name: Calculate simple probabilities from two way tables
Calculate conditional probabilities from two way tables

explanations.A: Only one child out of the 11 children is 12 years old and has a sister, so the probability is 1/11.
explanations.B: Not quite. This is the probability of picking a child that is 12 years olds and does not have a sister. We want the probability that they are 12 years old and does have a sister.
explanations.C: Not quite. I think you have found the probability of picking an 11 year old with a sister. We want the probability that the student is 12 years old and has a sister.
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you have found the probability of picking an 11 year old. We want the probability that the student is 12 years old and has a sister.

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you have found the probability of picking an 11 year old with a sister. We want the probability that the student is 12 years old and has a sister.
explanations.B: There are 14 children altogether and two of them are 12 and have a sister. Therefore the probability will be 2/14.
explanations.C: Not quite. This is the probability of picking a child that is 12 years olds and does not have a sister. We want the probability that they are 12 years old and does have a sister.
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you have found the probability of picking an 11 year old. We want the probability that the student is 12 years old and has a sister.

explanations.A: "Given that they have a sister" means we are only choosing from those that have a sister. So our total number of possible children is 5. This will be the denominator (bottom) of our fraction.
explanations.B: "Given that they have a sister" means we are only choosing from those that have a sister. How will this affect the total number of children we can choose from?
explanations.C: You have given the probability of choosing a 12 year old, but missed the first part of the question. What does "Given that they have a sister" mean?
explanations.D: I think you have mixed up the numerator and denominator. The denominator is the number at the bottom of the fraction and tells us the total children we are choosing from

explanations.A: I think you have confused the numerator and denominator. The numerator is the number on the top of a fraction and here it tells us the number of children who fit our criteria (12 years old and have a sister)
explanations.B: You have given the probability of choosing a 12 year old, but missed the first part of the question. What does "Given that they have a sister" mean?
explanations.C: Not quite. The numerator is the number on the top of a fraction and here it tells us the number of children who fit our criteria (12 years old and have a sister)
explanations.D: Only 1 child is 12 years old and has a sister, so this is the numerator.

explanations.A: You have given the probability of choosing a 12 year old, but missed the first part of the question. What does "Given that they have a sister" mean?
explanations.B: Only 2 children are 12 years old and have a sister, so this is the numerator.
explanations.C: I think you have confused the numerator and denominator. The numerator is the number on the top of a fraction and here it tells us the number of children who fit our criteria (12 years old and have a sister)
explanations.D: I think you have confused the numerator and denominator, and not taken into account the 'given that'. The numerator is the number on the top of a fraction and here it tells us the number of children who fit our criteria (12 years old and have a sister)

explanations.A: I think you have answered as if the probability was the other way around i.e. “Given that they have a sister…”.
explanations.B: "Given that they are 12 years old" means we are only choosing from those that are 12 years old. How will this affect the total number of children we can choose from?
explanations.C: "Given that they are 12 years old" means we are only choosing from those that are 12 years old. So our total number of possible children is 4. This will be the denominator (bottom) of our fraction.
explanations.D: I think you have mixed up the numerator and denominator. The denominator is the number at the bottom of the fraction and tells us the total children we are choosing from

explanations.B: "Given that they are 12 years old" means we are only choosing from those that are 12 years old. So our total number of possible children is 5. This will be the denominator (bottom) of our fraction.
explanations.C: I think you have mixed up the numerator and denominator. The denominator is the number at the bottom of the fraction and tells us the total children we are choosing from
explanations.D: I think you have answered as if the probability was the other way around i.e. “Given that they have a sister…”.

explanations.A: You have given the probability that they have a sister, but missed the first part of the question. What does "Given that they are 12 years old" mean?
explanations.B: I think you have confused the numerator and denominator. The numerator is the number on the top of a fraction and here it tells us the number of children who fit our criteria (12 years old and have a sister)
explanations.C: Nearly. You have chosen the numerator for "given that they are 12 years old, what is the probability they do not have a sister". Read the question again. Can you spot the difference?
explanations.D: There is one child that has a sister and is 12 years old, so this is the numerator.

explanations.A: I think you have confused the numerator and denominator. The numerator is the number on the top of a fraction and here it tells us the number of children who fit our criteria (12 years old and have a sister)
explanations.B: There are two children that have a sister and are 12 years old, so 2 is the numerator.
